oneOf.description: Data is about studying how genes are manifested or suppressed.
Data is about the large-scale study of proteins.
Data is about studying the observable characteristics of participants. This may or may not be paired with genotyping, as well.
Data is about the study and analysis of the collective genetic material and resultant files from the participant, microorganisms, and their environment.
Data is a list of participant MRNs.

Data is about notes, often free text, produced from visits to a healthcare provider. N.B. Data or files produced directly from collection information about the physical state of the participant should take the term "participant".

Data is about a defined set of information produced from visits to a healthcare provider. N.B. Data or files produced directly from collection information about the physical state of the participant should take the term "participant".
Describes how whole, discrete datasets comprising the series or collection are created, edited, and maintained.
Describes how files comprising the dataset are created, edited, and maintained.
Data is about a defined set of participants and defined set of information related to those participants.
Data is about how the study, experiment, or analysis is designed and initially run.
Data is about how the study, experiment, or analysis is conducted.
Data is about the archival governance of the study and its datasets.
Data is about and collected directly from living body of participant.
Videourodynamics (VUDS) fluoroscopic tracings.
The study of all a person or organism's genes and their functions.
Data collected from surveys.
Placeholder value.
Questionnaire or survey distributed to study participants. Should contain the actual question text and generally should not contain answers (i.e. this is a blank questionnaire).
Compiled set of survey of questionnaire responses, sometimes with additional analysis performed.
List of individuals who participated in the research effort.
File written in a coding language such as python or Structured Query Language (SQL).
Set of data consisting of information gathered during the course of clinical care visits.
Placeholder value.
The reference links out to the omics-protocols repository and contains all sequencing type values for Omics work.
Images produced from using a microscope.
Data produced from visits to a healthcare provider.
Data produced from visits to a healthcare provider or researcher conducting a study into the safety and effectiveness of a drug, medical device, or procedure.
Data is about a defined set of participants and defined set of information related to those participants.

Data related to the study and analysis of genes. Whenever possible, the most specific term available for describing the technique used in genomic analysis should be applied. For example, if a study used whole exome sequencing in their research, "exome sequence" should be supplied for dataTypeName in favor of "genomics".
A set of steps and tools for producing or analyzing data.
A file that names and describes data elements.
Code written in Structured Query Language (SQL) programming language used to query a database.
Placeholder value.
A human readable description of a Structured Query Language (SQL) query used to pull participant data matching given inclusion/exclusion criteria.
Code used to automate functions of data creation or analysis.
Information describing content and procedures used in the course of study or archiving.
Information about the set up and specifications for a study or workflow.
Files that provide information regarding the details of genomic analysis.
Files that provide information regarding the details of non-genomic analysis.
Data related to panel used to search for genetic mutations in tumors or cancer cells.
Materials used for the publication of data, reports, or papers related to a given study.
Set of clinical cases grouped together in the course of research. This clinical information was not originally collected for research purposes.

Data related to annotation of one particular positional feature on a biomolecular (typically genome) sequence, suitable for import and display in a genome browser. This term should be used for dataTypeName when there is a format value of "text/bed".
Images and image data from MRI, x-ray, etc.
Data and files showing measures of blood oxigenation.
Artifical intelligence and deep learning computer networks.
Videourodynamics (VUDS) fluoroscopic tracings.
Answers given by participants to questionnaries. When this term is used for dataTypeName, dataTypeMethod value should be "survey".
Data is a list of participant MRNs.
Data is an annotation of a genome.
Data is a summary of genetic composition.
Primary representation of genotype calls at biallelic variants (from https://www.cog-genomics.org/plink/1.9/formats).
Binary Alignment Map (BAM) files not mapped to a human reference genome. Commonly also referred to as uBAMS.

A gene change in a reproductive cell (egg or sperm) that becomes incorporated into the DNA of every cell in the body of the offspring. From: https://www.cancer.gov/publications/dictionaries/genetics-dictionary/def/germline-variant.
Data being manipulated or processed comes from Compressed Reference-oriented Alignment Map (CRAM) files.
In genomics, description of significance for a given gene location.
Extraction from a relational database. Can be direct extraction or extract and transform to different format, e.g. Comma Separated Value (CSV) files.
Quality control metrics for processes involving transformations.

Reports detailing the results of recalibration of genomics files. The recalibration process is often applied to unmapped Binary Alignment Map (BAM) files as they are processed into calibrated BAMs and downstream artifacts like Rompressed Reference-Oriented Alignment Map (CRAM) and Variant Call Format (VCF) files
The reference links out to the omics-protocols repository and contains all dataTypeSource genome build values for Omics work.
Data being manipulated or processed comes from the backend Epic database, Clarity.
Data being manipulated or processed comes from the Nautilus Laboratory Information Management System.

Data being manipulated or processed comes from the CHOP Clinical Data Warehouse (CDW). Portions of this warehouse pre-date CHOP Epic and Epic Clarity data. The CDW also includes data from sources outside of CHOP Epic and Epic Clarity, collected either before or concurrent with Epic implementation at CHOP.

Data being manipulated or processed comes from the REDCap data capture system. This information can include various types of data collection instruments, such as surveys, as well as survey responses and data dictionaries.

Data being manipulated or processed comes from either remote or local file storage. This can include cloud storage, such as that from Google Cloud Services (GCS) or Amazon Web Services (AWS), or files from a hard drive. This term should be used when describing a process that directly impacts the file system or where the file system is the main source for a process. For example, this term can be applied to a set of python script files designed to update file names on a data analyst's local computer.
Data being manipulated or processed comes from a Picture Archiving and Communication System (PACS). Information from the PACS can include both images and reports.
Data being manipulated or processed comes from a wearable object used to collect biological and environmental data. Example: FitBit.
Data being manipulated or processed comes from a Laboratory Information Management System (LIMS).
Data being manipulated or processed comes from a system outside of CHOP.
A biological sample itself, e.g. saliva, is being process or manipulated. In genomics, fastq files are produced from the processing of the biological sample.
Data being manipulated or processed comes from Binary Alignment Map (BAM) files. BAM files provide the source for genomic variant call format (gVCF) files.

Data being manipulated or processed comes from fastq files. Fastq files provide the source for alignment files such as Binary Alignment Map (BAM) files or compressed reference-oriented alignment map (CRAM) files.
Data being manipulated or processed comes from genomic variant call format (gVCF) files. gVCF files can provide the source for variant call format (VCF) files.
Data being manipulated or processed comes from the Pediatric Oncology Network Database (POND).
Data being manipulated or processed comes from a collection already in Arcus.
Data being manipulated or processed comes from raw IDAT files.
Data being manipulated or processed comes from or utilizes manifest files provided by Omics sequencing company. Files types often include .bpm, .egt, .csv.
Data is a summary of genetic composition.
Data is an annotation of a genome.
Data being manipulated or processed comes from Compressed Reference-oriented Alignment Map (CRAM) files.
Binary Alignment Map (BAM) files not mapped to a human reference genome. Commonly also referred to as uBAMS.
Binary Alignment Map (BAM) files created as part of a pipeline to serve as input. These files are typically not saved or archived.
Data come from a relational database. Examples include Presto or PostGres.
Placeholder value.
The date that the publisher accepted the resource into their system.
The date the resource is made publicly available. May be a range.
The date or date range in which the resource content was collected.
The specific, documented date at which the resource receives a copyrighted status, if applicable.

The date the resource itself was put together; this could refer to a timeframe in ancient history, be a date range or a single date for a final component, e.g. the finalized file with all of the data.
The date that the resource is published or distributed e.g. to a data centre
A date with a type other than the available values in the dateType vocabulary. Always check whether a type should be added to the vocabulary before using "other".
The date the creator submits the resource to the publisher. This could be different from Accepted if the publisher then applies a selection process.
The date of the last update to the resource, when the resource is being added to. May be a range.
The date or date range during which the dataset or resource is accurate.
The date the resource was ingested into archival storage.
The date cataloging work on the resource originally began.
The date the collection record for the resource was updated.
The date the resource was accessioned into the Archives.
The date the Data Contribution Agreement (DCA) was signed by the contributor.
The data the resource was deaccessioned (withdrawn) from the Archives.
The date additional content was accrued to the collection.

The date most relevant as a start date for the collection. This may be the date of funding, the initiation of data collection, or any other relevant date depending on the type and nature of the collection, and is best determined by the contributor.

The date most relevant as an end date for the collection. This may be the date of completion of funding, the end of data collection, or any other relevant date depending on the type and nature of the collection, and is best determined by the contributor.
Any date useful for describing the collection that does not fall under one of the existing collection specific dateType options.
Denotes the end of the retention period set out in the IRB protocol or other documentation. Data should be removed from the Archives in compliance with specifications of the protocol.
Placeholder value.
International Standard Name Identifier (ISNI). When using this value, set funderIdentifierTypeURI to "isni.org".
Global Research Identifier Database (GRID). When using this value, set funderIdentifierTypeURI to "grid.ac".
Crossref Funder Identifier. When using this value, set funderIdentifierTypeURI to "https://www.crossref.org/services/funder-registry".
Library of Congress Name Authority File (LCNAF). When using this value, set funderIdentifierTypeURI to "https://id.loc.gov/authorities/names.html".
Another value not specified.
Placeholder value.

identifiability.fieldSource: Controlled vocabulary includes a manually added local list as well as terms from the Arcus data tagging initiative

oneOf.description: Data contains full identifiers.
Can also be called pseudonymized or pseudonymization. Data contains substituted artificial identifiers in place of actual identifiable information.
Can also be called deidentified. Data has been stripped of identifiers.
Not enough information is available to make a determination about the level of identifability.
Information that if disclosed would require no special protection and could be released to the public (e.g. anything approved for mass distribution).

Any information whether oral, electronic, or on paper that involves Hospital Workforce information (e.g., payroll information), non-public Hospital business information, non-public research information, vendor trade secrets, Personally Identifiable Information or other confidential Hospital information.
Information that may identify an individual and relates to an individual's past, present, or future physical/mental health or condition, health care or payment for healthcare.
Determination of identifability does not apply.
Another value not specified.
Placeholder value.
Research exploring fundamental scientific principles.
Testing of scientific principles in a clinical setting, with human participants.
Research exploring the application of fundamental scientific principles.
Research exploring behavior and the impact of social factors on behavior.
Research relating to the spread of disease.
Collection of data curated about a specific disease, condition, participant, or group of participants.
Systematic assessment undertaken to improve the quality of care or processes of administering care.
Otherwise undefined or broad study.

A cohort of participants based on predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria. These cohorts can be associated with a particular program or can be basic predefined cohorts defined by Arcus staff. An example of the latter include a healthy controls cohort. The reference cohort collection type is also an Arcus archival workflow designation representing a specific set of procedures and structures.
A study using imaging techniques.
A study using genomic sequencing techniques.
Study utilizes or collects data in a relational database format.
Placeholder value.

relatedIdentifierType.fieldSource: DataCite Metadata Schema 4.0 plus manually added items

oneOf.description: Archival Resource Key (ARK); URL designed to support long‐term access to information objects. In general, ARK syntax is of the form (brackets indicate [optional] elements: [http://NMA/]ark:/NAAN/Name [Qualifier].

arXiv identifier; arXiv.org is a repository of preprints of scientific papers in the fields of mathematics, physics, astronomy, computer science, quantitative biology, statistics, and quantitative finance.

Astrophysics Data System bibliographic codes; a standardized 19 character identifier according to the syntax yyyyjjjjjvvvvmppppa. See http://info‐ uri.info/registry/OAIHandler?ve rb=GetRecord&metadataPrefix= reg&identifier=info:bibcode/.
Digital Object Identifier (DOI); a character string used to uniquely identify an object. A DOI name is divided into two parts, a prefix and a suffix, separated by a slash.

European Article Number (EAN), now renamed International Article Number, but retaining the original acronym, is a 13‐digit barcoding standard which is a superset of the original 12‐digit Universal Product Code (UPC) system.
Electronic International Standard Serial Number (EISSN); International Standard Serial Number (ISSN) used to identify periodicals in electronic form (eISSN or e‐ ISSN).
A handle is an abstract reference to a resource.
International Geo Sample Number (IGSN); a 9‐digit alphanumeric code that uniquely identifies samples from our natural environment and related sampling features.
International Standard Book Number (ISBN); a unique numeric book identifier. There are 2 formats: a 10‐digit ISBN format and a 13‐ digit ISBN.
International Standard Serial Number (ISSN); a unique 8‐digit number used to identify a print or electronic periodical publication.
International Standard Text Code (ISTC); a unique “number” assigned to a textual work. An ISTC consists of 16 numbers and/or letters.
Linking International Standard Serial Number (LISSN). The linking ISSN or ISSN‐L enables collocation or linking among different media versions of a continuing resource.
Life Science Identifiers (LSID); a unique identifier for data in the Life Science domain. Format: urn:lsid:authority:namespace:id entifier:revision.
PubMed identifier (PMID); a unique number assigned to each PubMed record.
Persistent Uniform Resource Locator (PURL). A PURL has three parts: (1) a protocol, (2) a resolver address, and (3) a name.
Universal Product Code (UPC) is a barcode symbology used for tracking trade items in stores. Its most common form, the UPC‐A, consists of 12 numerical digits.

Uniform Resource Locator (URL), also known as web address, is a specific character string that constitutes a reference to a resource. The syntax is: scheme://domain:port/path?qu ery_string#fragment_id.

Uniform Resource Name (URN); is a unique and persistent identifier of an electronic document. The syntax is: urn:< NID>:<NSS> The leading urn: sequence is case‐insensitive, <NID> is the namespace identifier, <NSS> is the namespace‐specific string.
Placeholder value.
Persistent Identifier (PID) representing a REDCap project.

Persistent Identifier representing an Arcus collection. The syntax is the letter C followed by the collection initiation date in ISO-8601 fomat followed by a 5 digit number. For example C2020010100035.

relatedIdentifierRelation.fieldSource: DataCite Metadata Schema 4.0 plus manually added items

oneOf.description: Indicates that B includes A in a citation.
Indicates that A includes A in a citation.
Indicates that A is a supplement to B.
Indicates that B is a supplement to A.
Indicates A is continued by the work B.
Indicates A is a continuation of the work B.
Indicates A is a new edition of B, where the new edition has been modified or updated.
Indicates A is a previous edition of B.
Indicates A is a portion of B; may be used for elements of a series.
Indicates A includes the part B.
Indicates A is used as a source of information by B.
Indicates B is used as a source of information for A.
Indicates B is documentation about/explaining A; e.g. points to software documentation.
Indicates A is documentation about/B; e.g. points to software documentation.
Indicates B is used to compile or create A.
Indicates B is the result of a compile or creation event using A.
Indicates A is a variant or different form of B.
Indicates A is the original form of B.
Indicates that A is identical to B, for use when there is a need to register two separate instances of the same resource.
Indicates resource A has additional metadata B.
Indicates additional metadata A for a resource B.
Indicates that A is a review of B.
Indicates that A is reviewed by B.
Indicates B is a source upon which A is based.
Indicates A is a source upon which B is based.
Indicates A describes B.
Indicates A is described by B.
Indicates A has a version (B).
Indicates A is a version of B.
Indicates A requires B.
Indicates A is required by B.
Placeholder value.
A brief description of the resource and the context in which the resource was created.
The methodology employed for the study or research.
Description providing details about the nature and content of the series.
oneOf.note: This definition differs from the one used in DataCite Metadata 4.3.

oneOf.description: A listing of the Table of Contents.
Detailed information that may be associated with design, implementation, operation, use, and/or maintenance of a process or system.
Other description information that does not fit into an existing category.
A short description explaining the basic features of the study.

Describes inclusion/exclusion criteria specifically structured and used for display in the ACD. This is more structured than the description provided in the protocol documentation and recorded as target population at the collection level. More detailed and granular information about inclusion/exclusion criteria should be listed in the studyCriteria field at the series level.
Placeholder value.
This collection is expected to receive additional or updated data or files on a regularly scheduled basis.
This research effort is complete and no additional updates or accruals are expected.
This research effort is complete however additional or updated data or files may be added to the collection on an intermittent, non-regularly-scheduled basis.
This research effort is still in process, so additional deposits of data and files are expected at least until completion of the effort.
Placeholder value.

studyStage.description: Describes where in the research lifecycle the project is. The "StudyStageRank" variable in in the aggregate_rules.go file is used for automatic accumulation of values. Cumulative values only roll the most complete studyStage up to series from across all constituent subseries. The value in the "StudyStageRank" variable orders values from begining to end of the research lifecycle with lower value meaning closer to project start.

oneOf.description: The study is in preparatory phases, full data collection has not yet begun.
The study is actively being conducted and data is in the process of being gathered.
Data collection is completed and the study team is now in the process of analyzing the data.
The study team is actively in the process of publishing findings from the study.
The study is complete and no additional data collection, analysis, or publication is happening at this time.
This concept does not apply.
Placeholder value.
This study has inclusion or exclusion criteria based on the age of participants.
This study has inclusion or exclusion criteria based on dates.
This study has inclusion or exclusion criteria based on the race and/or ethnicity of participants.
This study has inclusion or exclusion criteria based on the gender of participants.
This study has inclusion or exclusion criteria based on clinical care location. Examples include inpatient, outpatient, and ED.
This study has inclusion or exclusion criteria based on geographic location. Examples include city, zip code, and county.
International Classification of Diseases (ICD). This study has inclusion or exclusion criteria based on patient diagnosis.
This study has inclusion or exclusion critera based on prescribed or administered medications.
This study has inclusion or exclusion criteria based on lab tests.
This study has inclusion or exclusion critera based on procedures.
This study has inclusion or exlusion criteria based on the visit type.
This study has inclusion or exclusion criteria based on the completion of a questionnaire or form.
This study has inclusion or exclusion criteria based on the presence or absence of patient allergens.
This study has inclusion or exclusion criteria based on the spoken or written language of the participant or their family. Language codes to be determined.
This study has inclusion or exclusion criteria based on a screener from the study team making a decision as to whether a patient can fit into the study.
This study has inclusion or exclusion criteria based on the relationship of a potential participant to a confirmed participant in the study.
Placeholder value.

The Protocol Identifier comes from the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia Institutional Review Board (IRB). If the IRB number is automatically populated from the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia electronic Institutional Review Board (eIRB) system, set "@studyProtocolIDSource" value to "eIRB".
The Protocol Identifier comes from the Institutional Review Board (IRB) at the University of Pennsylvania.
Placeholder value.
Protocol dealing with a study that involves human subjects research as determined by the appropriate Institutional Review Board (IRB).
Protocol dealing with a study that does not involve human subjects research as determined by the appropriate Institutional Review Board (IRB).
Protocol dealing with a study that involves human subjects research to determine the safety and/or effectiveness of a device, medication, or therapy.
A protocol type not listed. If using this value, please provide explanation in the @studyProtocolNote field.
Placeholder value.

studyTreatment.description: This will be used to describe clinical trials and will eventually need to be populated either with Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) terms or with terms from a different ontology. At this time because we do not have any clinical trial data, that final decision has not been made.

oneOf.description: Medical Subject Headings (MeSH).
Placeholder value.
TBD

oneOf.const: yes, at least one dataset has a CoC
oneOf.description: This should be used if any data set in the collection has a certificate of confidentiality (CoC).
Use this value only if NO datasets in the entire collection have certificates of confidentiality (CoC).
The reference links out to the omics-protocols repository and contains all values for the software program or tool used to to manipulate files in Omics work.
The reference links out to the omics-protocols repository and contains all aligner values for Omics work.
The reference links out to the omics-protocols repository and contains all strand name values for Omics SNP Array work.
Data was produced by a modality for creating images. This can include x-rays, MRIs, ultrasounds, etc.
Data was produced through a structured study of the effects of a drug or device on participants.
Data was produced and/or manipulated using Structured Query Language (SQL) queries.
Data was collected or manipulated using the REDCap data capture system.
Data was collected over a protracted period of time.
Data was produced or manipulated using python 2 programming language.
Data was produced or manipulated using python 3 programming language.
Data was produced through a manual, non-automated process.
Data was produced using an extract, transform, load (ETL) process to manipulate the data.
Data was produced using the STATA version 14.2 statistics and data science program.

oneOf.const: Long Short Term Memory Recurrent Neural Network
oneOf.description: Long Short Term Memory Recurrent Neural Network (LSTM RNN).
TBD
vt is a variant tool set that discovers short variants from Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) data.
Questionnaire administered to participants, usually standardized.
Jupyter notebooks, a web-based interactive computing platform.
Placeholder value.
The reference links out to the omics-protocols repository and contains all dataTypePlatform instrument model values for Omics work.
The reference links out to the omics-protocols repository and contains all manufacturer values for Omics work.
Data was produced using a mass spectrometer analytical tool.
Data was collected using a wearable device. Example: FitBit.
Data was produced or manipulated using Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) genomic techniques. Whenever possible, the most specific term available for describing the NGS technique should be applied.
Data was produced or manipulated using python 2 programming language.
Data was produced or manipulated using python 3 programming language.
Data was produced or manipulated using the Google Cloud Platform (GCP) Dataflow cloud service for running Apache Beam.
Data was produced or manipulated using the Google Cloud Platform (GCP) Dataproc cloud service for running Apache Spark and Apache Hadoop.
Data was produced or manipulated using Apache Beam version 2.7.0 programming model.
Data was produced or manipulated using the Apache Spark analytics model.
Data was produced or manipulated using Structured Query Language (SQL) programming language.
Data was produced using JavaScript Object Notation (JSON).
Data was produced using Yet Another Markup Language (YAML) notation.
Data was produced using the STATA version 14.2 statistics and data science program.
Siemens brand MRI machine.
Database run my Medical Decision Logix.
Epic electronic health record system.
A method to view the inside of the body using high-frequency sound waves.
Neurocognitive survey. Also referred to by acronym "CNB".
Research Electronic Data Capture system.
Jupyter notebooks, a web-based interactive computing platform.
Placeholder value.
Data has not been analyzed or manipulated. It is in the same state as when it was collected.
Raw data that has been cleaned to remove common errors or noise. Preprocessing does not produce substantial analysis.
Data has been analyzed.
Data that has been curated. This could mean it was cleaned, rearranged, or some other manipulation that resulted in a different presentation of the data.
Data presented in a simplified fashion, often with the aim of communicating general trends.
Data that is the result of some process being applied to either raw or manipulated data.
Information that describes another set of data.
Technical information that describes how data has been manipulated.
Genomic data that has been aligned to a reference genome.
Data that notes variations within a genomic sequence, usually compared to a reference genome.
Jupyter notebooks, a web-based interactive computing platform.
Placeholder value.
Fecal matter.
Blood (location, component, or type unspecified).
Sample gathered by swabbing subject's tongue.
Sample gathered by swabbing interior of subject's cheek.
Sample gathered by swabbing subject's rectum.
Oral saliva sample collected directly from pooling in subject's mouth or by swab.
Tissue (location or type unspecified).
Sample gathered from contents of subject's ostomy bag or by swabbing subject's ostomy bag.
Sample gathered from contents of subject's ostomy bag or by swabbing subject's ostomy bag.
Sample gathered from contents of subject's ostomy bag or by swabbing subject's ostomy bag.
Sample gathered from contents of subject's ostomy bag or by swabbing subject's ostomy bag.
Sample gathered from contents of subject's ostomy bag or by swabbing subject's ostomy bag.
Sample gathered from contents of subject's ostomy bag or by swabbing subject's ostomy bag.
Sample gathered from contents of subject's ostomy bag or by swabbing subject's ostomy bag.
Sample gathered from contents of subject's ostomy bag or by swabbing subject's ostomy bag.

oneOf.const: residual tissue and fluid specimens obtained for clinical indications
oneOf.description: Sample gathered from contents of subject's ostomy bag or by swabbing subject's ostomy bag.
Placeholder value.
A series of visual representations imparting an impression of motion when shown in succession. May or may not include sound.
An aggregation of resources, which may encompass collections of one resourceType as well as those of mixed types. A collection is described as a group; its parts may also be separately described.
A factual and objective publication with a focused intent to identify and describe specific data, sets of data, or data collections to facilitate discoverability.
Data encoded in a defined structure.
A non-persistent, timebased occurrence.
A visual representation other than text.
A resource requiring interaction from the user to be understood, executed, or experienced.
An abstract, conceptual, graphical, mathematical or visualization model that represents empirical objects phenomena, or physical processes.
An inanimate, three-dimensional object or substance.
An organized system of apparatus, appliances, staff, etc., for supplying some function(s) required by end users.
A computer program in source code (text) or compiled form. Use this type for all software components supporting scholarly research.
A resource primarily intended to be heard.
A resource consisting primarily of words for reading.
A structured series of steps which can be executed to produce a final outcome, allowing users a means to specify and enact their work in a more reproducible manner.
If selected, supply a value for ResourceType.
Placeholder value.
This is a criterion used to select participants INTO the study group.
This is a criterion used to select participants OUT OF the study group.
Placeholder value.
The reference links out to the file that contains the historical affiliationDepartment and Division terms.

oneOf.const: Dept Of Anesthesiology And Critical Care Medicine - Research

oneOf.description: The reference links out to the file that contains the historical affiliationDepartment and Division terms.
A brief description of the resource and the context in which the resource was created.
The methodology employed for the study or research.
Information about a series or subseries.
oneOf.note: This definition differs than the one used in DataCite Metadata 4.3.

oneOf.description: A listing of the Table of Contents.
Detailed information that may be associated with design, implementation, operation, use, and/or maintenance of a process or system.
Other description information that does not fit into an existing category.
Describes the setting and rationale for the study. Includes subsections for introduction, relevant literature and data, and compliance statement.
Describes the overall objectives of the study. Includes subsections for primary objectives (or aim) and secondary objectives (or aim).

Describes the study population using inclusion and exclusion criteria, regardless of study design. For each subject group, there needs to be separate inclusion/exclusion criteria. For example, the control population may have different selection criteria than the population with the disease or condition of interest. This field is related to inclusion/exclusion criteria summary description type but is free text and taken directly from protocol documentation.
Describes the interventions/procedures that will take place as part of the study.
Describes the main study outcome measures/endpoints.
A combined description including sections: background rationale, objectives, target population, interventions, study outcome measures.
Description sourced from the study protocol documentation other than any section included in the structured study abstract.
Description of the collection from an archival standpoint, usually created during the data contribution process.
Describes any relevant historical information related to the collection.
Description of the contents and extent of the collection, usually created by an archivist during the data contribution process.
Brief description of the collection not sourced from protocol documentation, usually created by the PI or someone on the study team.

Describes inclusion/exclusion criteria specifically structured and used for display in the ACD. This is more structured than the description provided in the protocol documentation and recorded as target population. More detailed and granular information about inclusion/exclusion criteria should be listed in the studyCriteria field at the series level.
Placeholder value.
Indicates the name provided represents an organization and not a single person.
Indicates the name provided represents an individual person and not an organization.
Placeholder value.

personType.fieldSource: DataCite Metadata Schema 4.3, University of Massachusetts Amherst Research Administration Policy, plus manually added items

oneOf.description: A Principal Investigator is the primary individual responsible for the preparation, conduct, and administration of a research grant, cooperative agreement, training or public service project, contract, or other sponsored project in compliance with applicable laws and regulations and institutional policy governing the conduct of sponsored research.
An institution sponsoring or producing the materials.

Co-investigators (Co-Is) are key personnel who have responsibilities similar to that of a Principal Investigator (PI) on research projects. While the PI has ultimate responsibility for the conduct of a research project, the Co-I is also obligated to ensure the project is conducted in compliance with applicable laws and regulations and institutional policy governing the conduct of sponsored research.
Also, clinical research coordinator. A person, not necessarily a clinician, responsible for the conduct of the clincal trial.

Lead investigators are key personnel who have responsibilities similar to that of a Principal Investigator (PI) on research projects.  While the PI has ultimate responsibility for the conduct of a research project, the lead investigator is also obligated to ensure the project is conducted in compliance with applicable laws and regulations and institutional policy governing the conduct of sponsored research.

A member of the group who supports the science or conduct of the research effort in ways that may not be directly related to the science of the study, e.g. administration. When possible, a more specific term should be used to describe the person's role.
Person or group of people requesting to recieve data.
Data integration analyst (DIA). A person responsible for cleaning, normalizing, and unifying data and datsets.

A person in an academic research position at a university or a similar research institution, usually for academic staff or faculty members. A research fellow may act either as an independent investigator or under the supervision of a principal investigator.
A member of the group working directly on the science of a research study. When possible, a more specific term should be used to describe the person's role.
A person or group of people working as part of a single laboratory.
A group of people, often across varying departments, working together to advance a single goal or knowledge on a single topic.
Person responsible for using biology, computer science, information engineering, mathematics and statistics to analyze and interpret the biological data.

Co-Principal Investigators (co-PIs) are key personnel who have responsibilities similar to that of a Principal Investigator (PI) on research projects. The PI and co-PI or group of co-PIs may share ultimate responsibility for the conduct of a research project. Co-PIs are obligated to ensure the project is conducted in compliance with applicable laws and regulations and institutional policy governing the conduct of sponsored research.
Person responsible for creating reports, analyzing data, troubleshooting, researching and fixing issues.
Person with knowledge of how to access, troubleshoot, or otherwise field issues related to the resource.
Person/institution responsible for finding, gathering, and/or collecting data under the guidelines of the author(s) or Principal Investigator (PI).
Person tasked with reviewing, enhancing, cleaning, or standardizing metadata and the associated data submitted for storage, use, and maintenance within a data centre or repository.
Person (or organisation with a staff of data managers, such as a data centre) responsible for maintaining the finished resource.
Institution tasked with responsibility to generate/disseminate copies of the resource in either electronic or print form.
A person who oversees the details related to the publication format of the resource.
Typically, the organisation allowing the resource to be available on the internet through the provision of its hardware/software operating support.
Typically a person or organisation responsible for the artistry and form of a media product.
Person officially designated as head of project team or subproject team instrumental in the work necessary to development of the resource.
Person officially designated as manager of a project. Project may consist of one or many project teams and sub-teams.
Person on the membership list of a designated project/project team.
Institution/organisation officially appointed by a Registration Authority to handle specific tasks within a defined area of responsibility.
A standards-setting body from which Registration Agencies obtain official recognition and guidance.
A person without a specifically defined role in the development of the resource, but who is someone the author wishes to recognize.

A person involved in analyzing data or the results of an experiment or formal study. May indicate an intern or assistant to one of the authors who helped with research but who was not so 'key' as to be listed as an author.
Typically refers to a group of individuals with a lab, department, or division; the group has a particular, defined focus of activity.
Person or institution owning or managing property rights including intellectual property rights over the resource.
Person or organisation that issued a contract or under the auspices of which a work has been written, printed, published, developed, etc.
Designated administrator over one or more groups/teams working to produce a resource or over one or more steps of a development process.

A Work Package is a recognized data product, not all of which is included in publication. The package, instead, may include notes, discarded documents, etc. The Work Package Leader is responsible for ensuring the comprehensive contents, versioning, and availability of the Work Package during the development of the resource.
Person resonsible for the arrangement, processing, and preservation of the materials related to the study.
Person responsible for reviewing regulatory and subject protection documentation to determine what restrictions or conditions need to be placed on the data.
Person responsible for statistical analysis and reporting of study data.
A person professionally conducting research after the completion of their doctoral studies.
A person working with the main study team. They may work on a specfic topic or area or more broadly.
Any person or institution making a significant contribution to the development and/or maintenance of the resource, but whose contribution does not fit other controlled vocabulary terms.
Placeholder value.

oneOf.const: MeSH substance term or supplementary concept
oneOf.description: Medical Subject Headings (MeSH).
TBD
Placeholder value.
Series that holds information regarding the process of arranging, ingesting, and describing a collection.
Series that holds information regarding the conduct and logistics of the research study.
Series that holds files needed to understand the way research in the study was conducted both for analysis and publication.
Series that holds tools, methods, and/or models used in the conduct of the study.
Series which holds files that maintain descriptions of data along with samples and their associated files and metadata in raw and processed formats.
Access Tools subseries that holds models used in the conduct of the study. These can include but are not limited to machine learning models, model predictions, and model summaries.

The src, or sources, subseries is an Access Tools subseries that holds various tools or methods used in the conduct of the study. These can include but are not limited to workflows, custom scripts, tests, and/or Jupyter notebooks.
Contextual Files subseries that holds configuration files for workflows and applications.
Contextual Files subseries that holds IRBs, reference papers, sample information, and lab prep instructions.
Contextual Files subseries that holds content for producing reports, papers, metrics, and websites associated with the project.
Contextual Files subseries that holds module or library dependencies for workflows.
Research Data subseries that holds the final results from research analysis and/or files generated to support papers or grants.
Research Data subseries that holds intermediate or temporary files.
Research Data subseries that holds lab-created, CHOP Center-created, or externally created data that has not been analyzed or altered.
The ref-data, or reference data, subseries is a Research Data subseries that holds external or public datasets not supplied by Research Information Services or a CHOP lab.
Archival Administration File subseries that holds files used in the preparation of collection files for archiving.
Archival Administration File subseries that holds documents relating to refining details surrounding the access conditions and discovery preferences for the collection.
Archival Administration File subseries that holds documents relating to the evaluation of the institutional and intellectual value of the collection.
Archival Administration File subseries that holds communications, drafts, and final versions of the collection's data contribution agreement (DCA).

Archival Administration File subseries that holds information relating to the conduct of the archival data survey, used to understand what data and contextual files were produced in the study and should be archived.
Archival Administration File subseries that holds specifications about the archival ingestion process for the collection.
Archival Administration File subseries that holds documents related to the legal and privacy due diligence process.
Archival Administration File subseries that holds documents related to meetings held between the Arcus team and the study team in the process of ingesting the collection.
Archival Administration File subseries that holds documents related to metadata creation, updating, validation, and approval.
Archival Administration File subseries that holds documents related to archival processing and arrangement.
Archival Administration File (AAF) subseries that holds documents related to archival processing and arrangement. This part of the AAF holds the accession record created by the archivist.
Placeholder value.
Arcus Clinical Data Repository (ACDR).
CHOP's electronic Institutional Review Board system (eIRB).
CHOP's REDCap instance.
The protocol documents associated with one or more of the protocol ID numbers listed in this collection.
The corresponding entry for this research study on found in the clinicaltrials.gov database.
Placeholder value.

A subordinate name for the object.
A name for the object in a language other than the original, full name.

Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP) Medical Record Number (MRN).

Identifier assigned by Arcus for a participant in a given collection. Often assigned when participant is in an Arcus collection but do not have a Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP) Medical Record Number (MRN).
